paragraph: “Blessed is he, the earth-born man, who hath seen this!    Who hath not shared in these divine ceremonies,    He hath an unequal fate in the obscure darkness of death.”Immortality is inherent in the Eleusinian symbol; in a church song of the nineteenth century by Samuel Preiswerk we discover it again:“The world is yours, Lord Jesus,         The world, on which we stand,         Because it is thy world         It cannot perish.         Only the wheat, before it comes         Up to the light in its fertility,         Must die in the bosom of the earth         First freed from its own nature.“Thou goest, O Lord, our chief,         To heaven through thy sorrows,         And guide him who believes         In thee on the same path.         Then take us all equally         To share in thy sorrows and kingdoms,         Guide us through thy gate of death,         Bring thy world into the light.”Firmicus relates concerning the Attis mysteries:“Nocte quadam simulacrum in lectica supinum ponitur et per numeros  digestis fletibus plangitur; deinde cum se ficta lamentatione  satiaverint, lumen infertur: tunc a sacerdote omnium qui flebant  fauces unguentur, quibus perunctis sacerdos hoc lento murmure  susurrat: ‘Θαρρεῖτε μύσται τοῦ Θεοῦ σεσωσμένου ἔσται γὰρ ἡμῖν ἐκ πόνου  σωτηρία.’”[683][Illustration: THE SO-CALLED HOLY SEPULCHRE OF S. STEFANO AT BOLOGNA]Only a few of the further deeds of Hiawatha can interest us here. Among these is the battle with Mishe-Nahma, the fish-king, in the eighth song. This deserves to be mentioned as a typical battle of the sun-hero. Mishe-Nahma is a fish monster, who dwells at the bottom of the waters. Challenged by Hiawatha to battle, he devours the hero, together with his boat:
question: What does Firmicus describe about the Attis mysteries, and what is the significance of the words spoken by the sacerdote?
answer: Firmicus describes the Attis mysteries as involving a scene where a supine image is placed on a bed and mourned with weeping and lamentation. The significance of the words spoken by the sacerdote, "Θαρρεῖτε μύσται τοῦ Θεοῦ σεσωσμένου ἔσται γὰρ ἡμῖν ἐκ πόνου σωτηρία," is that they encourage the initiates, or mystai, and promise them that through the death of the divine figure, they will find salvation and escape from suffering. This highlights the transformative power of these mysteries and the promise of immortality or spiritual salvation.
